Foreword
We have officially entered the Age of Artificial Intelligence. 
The world is now set to change at a pace not seen in decades, 
even centuries. AI-based tools and applications make our lives 
easier, smoother and richer. They help us move efficiently, get 
informed, get credit, get a job or get our taxes done.
But in its current form, AI reproduces and amplifies many of 
the social challenges we face. It is not acceptable that around 
one-third of the world’s population still lacks adequate internet 
access. Upstream, the AI industry is highly concentrated, with 
just two countries – the United States and China – and a dozen 
companies accounting for a major share of the sector. This can 
only lead to greater inequality of outcomes – including gender 
disparities – downstream. Non-diverse AI teams, unrepresentative datasets, and opaque and biased 
algorithms can cause harm, particularly to those who are already vulnerable, whether companies or 
individuals, children and young people, women or entire democracies.
That is why UNESCO drafted the Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence, which was 
adopted by 193 countries in 2021, to make sure AI delivers fair, sustainable and inclusive outcomes. 
The Recommendation is based on the protection and promotion of human rights, human dignity 
and environmental sustainability, and these values are then translated into principles such as 
accountability, transparency and privacy. The Recommendation also sets out concrete policy actions 
that governments can draw on to steer technological developments in a responsible direction, 
premised on the belief that light-touch regulation, which has been the norm until now, is insufficient. 
We need capable governments that are well equipped, in terms of competencies, institutions and 
laws, to frame responsible AI development and protect the rule of law online; and public and private 
developers who are accountable for putting human rights and fundamental freedoms – not profits 
or geopolitical considerations – first.
The Readiness Assessment Methodology (RAM) is a diagnostic tool intended to assist Member States 
in upholding their commitment to the Recommendation by helping them understand how prepared 
they are to implement AI ethically and responsibly for all their citizens. By highlighting any institutional, 
regulatory or data gaps and obstacles, it enables UNESCO to tailor support for governments to fill 
those gaps to ensure an ethical AI ecosystem aligned with the Recommendation.
Overall, this report presents a fundamentally optimistic vision that we at UNESCO share: that ethical 
governance and responsible regulation of AI is entirely consistent with innovation and economic 
growth and is essential for ensuring a technological ecosystem that benefits the public good. With 
the RAM data and this report, Maldives has a clear roadmap for how to get there.

recommendations.title: Priority
recommendations.text: Priority: high Develop anti-discrimination policies for AI Anti-discrimination principles should be integrated into all AI regulations in Maldives to prevent biases in AI systems, ensuring equitable treatment of all individuals regardless of gender, disability or other characteristics. As stated in the UNESCO Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence, AI actors should promote social justice, fairness and non-discrimination, ensuring the benefits of AI Dimension Recommendation Responsible institution Time frame Priority

recommendations.text: Responsible institution: Ministry of Homeland Security and Technology

recommendations.title: Priority
recommendations.text: Priority: high Develop policies on open data and data sharing Policies on open data and data sharing should be developed, and campaigns to change mindsets in this regard should be initiated, to avoid a siloed working culture and promote collaborative, data- driven functioning. This could lead to increased availability of Maldives-specific AI training data (in Dhivehi and including culturally specific datasets) through standardized open-source repositories, for example, while protecting data privacy with a comprehensive data protection law. This law should be aligned with international standards to safeguard personal data and enhance public trust in AI technologies. UNESCO has published guidelines for Member States on how to open their data in a sustainable manner, how to build capacities in this regard, and how to build an open-data-driven culture (UNESCO, 2023b). Data-sharing initiatives, such as those by the Maldives Bureau of Statistics or the planned Data Sharing Platform for Climate Action (D4DInsights, 2025) could also lay the groundwork for AI systems.

recommendations.title: Responsible institution
recommendations.text: Responsible institution: Ministry of Finance and Planning

recommendations.title: Priority
recommendations.text: Priority: high Create specific AI procurement guidelines Specific guidelines for the procurement of AI technologies within public sector projects should be formulated to ensure transparency, cybersecurity, fairness and adherence to ethical standards. To mitigate the risks of biased algorithms and security vulnerabilities, clear policies must be established to regulate the procurement of AI systems. These policies should outline necessary criteria for purchasing AI systems, including requirements for ethical compliance, technical robustness and alignment with national AI goals and standards. The policies should specifically include accessibility requirements for persons with disabilities. The accessibility should be tested and endorsed by persons with disabilities. By setting these standards, the government can ensure that AI systems are developed with ethical considerations in mind. A national-level coordinating initiative can harmonize sector-specific AI procurement needs and policies by establishing standardized guidelines and frameworks. This could include developing model contracts and procurement templates. These policies should also include mechanisms for the evaluation and oversight of contracted AI systems, with regular assessments to guarantee compliance with established guidelines. This allows for the continuous improvement of AI systems and their adaptation to evolving standards and societal needs, ensuring that AI systems remain aligned with government objectives.

recommendations.title: Priority
recommendations.text: Priority: medium 33 Enhance cybersecurity regulations to protect AI systems A bill on cybersecurity to enhance the scope of the National Cyber Security Agency should be enacted, with a view to ensuring the integrity and security of data used in AI applications. Given Maldives’ very low ranking in terms of cybersecurity, it is crucial to protect AI systems from vulnerabilities and threats, including against critical infrastructure. AI systems rely on vast amounts of data, making them vulnerable to data breaches and cyberattacks. If compromised, AI systems can be manipulated to produce biased or incorrect results, leading to harmful consequences for users of these systems. Cybersecurity measures like encryption and secure authentication can help prevent such threats. Effective cybersecurity also ensures the integrity and reliability of AI decision-making processes. By protecting AI systems, cybersecurity helps maintain trust in these technologies and prevents potential harm.

recommendations.title: Priority
recommendations.text: Priority: high Create a multistakeholder advisory council An advisory council comprising representatives from government, civil society, academia and the private sector should be established to provide insights, strategic guidance and recommendations on AI policy and regulation and to ensure transparency and accountability. Given the digital divide between the Greater Male' region and other islands, it will be critical that representatives from these islands are members of the advisory council. Also, persons with disabilities should be represented in the advisory council. The advisory council would facilitate dialogue among stakeholders, identify emerging AI trends and issues, and provide recommendations on how to address them. Additionally, the council could help ensure that AI policies align with Maldivian national values and priorities. It could also foster international collaboration and knowledge-sharing on AI governance.

recommendations.title: Responsible institution
recommendations.text: Responsible institution: President’s Office

recommendations.title: Priority
recommendations.text: Priority: high 34 Establish an AI Centre of Excellence to foster collaborations and partnerships Maldives might consider establishing an AI Centre of Excellence to serve as a hub for innovation and research and development in AI. This centre would bring together experts from academia, industry and government to collaborate on AI projects and to drive innovation. The centre could learn from the existing Centre of Excellence for Public Safety67 and could be affiliated with Maldives National University. An AI Centre of Excellence would also provide training and capacity-building programmes, fostering a skilled workforce and promoting a culture of AI-driven innovation in Maldives. These activities could include partnerships with government entities and academic institutions to promote research and the sharing of best practices in AI. Moreover, an AI Centre of Excellence could host incubators, accelerators and co-working spaces for AI start-ups. International collaboration would be crucial for such a centre as international partnerships could enable functions that Maldives does not necessarily have the capacity or resources to undertake, such as auditing and testing. This would also allow the products of Maldives to align with international standards, paving the way for international market access.

recommendations.title: Responsible institution
recommendations.text: Responsible institution: Ministry of Economic Development and Trade

recommendations.title: Priority
recommendations.text: Priority: medium Develop sector-specific AI task forces AI task forces should be formed within key sectors (e.g. healthcare, education, environment, finance and tourism) so that their experienced personnel can harness the full potential of AI by tailoring AI strategies to address the challenges and opportunities unique to their fields. These task forces could identify sector-specific AI applications, develop guidelines for responsible adoption and ensure that AI solutions are aligned with the sector’s goals and values. In healthcare, for example, AI-powered diagnostic tools can analyse medical images to help doctors detect diseases earlier and more accurately. In education, AI-driven adaptive learning systems can tailor educational content to individual students’ needs, abilities and learning styles. For the environment, AI-powered monitoring systems can analyse satellite imagery and sensor data to track rising sea-levels, predict coastal erosion and identify areas most vulnerable to climate change, enabling proactive conservation efforts. In finance, AI-based fraud-detection systems can analyse transaction patterns to identify and prevent fraudulent activities, reducing financial losses and protecting customers. In the tourism sector, AI-powered chatbots can provide personalized travel recommendations, offer real- time booking assistance and help visitors plan their trips to Maldives.

recommendations.title: Priority
recommendations.text: Priority: medium Preserve the cultural diversity and heritage of Maldives through AI A dedicated advisory board of experts within the current institutional framework should be created to focus on preserving the unique cultural identity and heritage of Maldives, using AI. As stated in 67 https://www.police.gov.mv/media/news/22730 35 the UNESCO Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence, ‘Member States are encouraged to leverage AI systems to preserve, promote and manage cultural heritage. This can be achieved by incorporating AI into educational programs and ensuring a participatory approach that involves institutions and the public. Additionally, Member States should assess the cultural impact of AI systems, particularly natural language processing applications, on human language and expression. This assessment should inform strategies that maximize the benefits of AI while addressing negative implications, such as the potential disappearance of endangered languages and cultural variations’ (UNESCO, 2022). This involves integrating local cultural content into AI training datasets to ensure that AI systems reflect and respect the cultural diversity of Maldives. This can be facilitated by community- driven AI projects that aim to document, preserve and promote local cultural practices and heritage, for which the participation of women, the elderly and people who live on islands beyond the Greater Male' region is essential.

recommendations.title: Priority
recommendations.text: Priority: high 68 https://csti.gov.mv/ 36 Conduct public awareness campaigns on AI Campaigns should be launched to educate the public about AI, its benefits and its potential risks, fostering a culture of informed engagement with AI technologies, thereby tackling the prevailing negative perception of, or lack of knowledge about, AI in Maldives. These campaigns could include workshops, seminars and online resources to educate the public about AI’s capabilities, limitations and potential impacts on society. By promoting a nuanced understanding of AI, such campaigns can help alleviate concerns and misconceptions, fostering a more informed and balanced public discourse. Additionally, the campaigns can highlight the opportunities and benefits of AI, such as improved healthcare, education and preservation of cultural heritage, and environmental conservation, as well as economic growth, especially related to tourism. By promoting diversity and inclusion, such campaigns can also help create a more equitable and vibrant AI ecosystem in Maldives.

recommendations.title: Priority
recommendations.text: Priority: high Increase the number of STEM and AI graduates, especially females Science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) and AI-related subjects should occupy an important place in schools from an early stage. This could spark students’ interest, including that of young girls, in these fields and prepare them for further studies. Scholarships and financial incentives could be offered to students pursuing STEM and AI-related degrees, making these fields more attractive and accessible. Partnerships with international universities and institutions could also provide opportunities for Maldivian students to study abroad and gain exposure to cutting-edge technologies. Moreover, the government could work with the private sector to provide internships, apprenticeships and job opportunities for STEM and AI graduates, ensuring that they are able to apply their skills and knowledge as part of the workforce. By creating a pipeline of opportunities, the government can encourage more students to pursue an education in STEM and AI-related fields, thus increasing the number of graduates in these areas. A particular focus should be on girls and women, given their strong performances in mathematics and interest in new technologies. This requires addressing and overcoming the stereotypes and barriers that women face in the field by featuring female role models and success stories, for example, thus inspiring and encouraging women to pursue careers in AI. Moreover, women’s participation in AI can also help address the gender biases that may be embedded in AI systems, ensuring that these technologies are fair, transparent and accountable. Another target group for education in STEM and AI-related subjects should be potential students from islands beyond the Greater Male' region. By increasing the participation of women and young students in STEM and AI-related subjects, Maldives can tap into a vast pool of talent, bringing diverse perspectives and ideas to the table. This

recommendations.title: Responsible institution
recommendations.text: Responsible institution: Ministry of Higher Education, Labour and Skills Development

recommendations.title: Priority
recommendations.text: Priority: high 37 Support and invest in research and development initiatives Funding and resources for AI research, development and infrastructure must be provided to stimulate innovation and encourage local solutions that address national challenges. This should include public-private partnerships and supporting start-ups. AI products should not only be consumed but also produced in Maldives, which requires the government to support the private sector, especially start-ups, in its efforts. Building more data centres within Maldives should also be facilitated. At the same time, AI research and development must take into account its impact on the environment and on the labour market. As such, the government should ensure that AI initiatives prioritize sustainability, job creation and upskilling programmes to mitigate potential negative impacts. This balanced approach will allow Maldives to harness the benefits of AI while protecting its unique environment and workforce. Overall, AI research and development in Maldives should be aligned with the Sustainable Development Goals (UN General Assembly, 2015).

recommendations.title: Responsible institution
recommendations.text: Responsible institution: Ministry of Economic Development and Trade and Ministry of Finance and Planning

recommendations.title: Priority
recommendations.text: Priority: medium Encourage lifelong learning in AI skills Lifelong learning initiatives that allow professionals to continuously update their skills in AI and related fields should be promoted, ensuring the workforce remains competitive and adaptable to technological advancements. The UNESCO Institute for Lifelong Learning provides guidance in this regard.69 Such initiatives can include workshops, training programmes and online courses that focus on emerging AI trends and technologies. Given opportunities to upskill and reskill, the workforce can stay abreast of the latest developments in AI, enabling people to innovate and adapt to changing industry needs. Additionally, partnerships with leaders of the private sector and academia can help ensure that these initiatives are tailored to the specific needs of the workforce. Lifelong learning initiatives can also be tailored to support professionals transitioning into AI-related fields, providing them with the necessary skills and knowledge to succeed. By fostering a culture of continuous learning, Maldives can develop a workforce that is agile, adaptable and equipped to thrive in an AI-driven global economy. Moreover, lifelong learning can help counter age discrimination in the workplace, enabling older professionals to continue contributing their expertise and experience. For this reason, it is essential to tailor lifelong learning initiatives to meet the unique needs and preferences of older learners, taking into account their prior knowledge, learning styles and career goals. By doing so, Maldives can ensure that its workforce remains inclusive and diverse, leveraging the skills and experience of professionals across all age groups.

Education The educational response of Maldives to digitalization, including AI, has been shaped by recent history.
In practice, the use of AI for pedagogical purposes remains ad hoc, depending on individual initiative.
Educators who wish to use AI are expected to inform both students and the responsible ministry.
strengths: Relevant government bodies, such as the National Centre for Information Technology and the recently established National Cyber Security Agency44 do not have dedicated centres or departments related to AI ethics, but do include AI ethics as a responsibility within their operations.
gaps: However, Maldives does have several projects with research and development components, undertaken with the assistance of external partners.

There are currently no Kaggle Grandmasters from Maldives, reflecting the limited scale of AI-specific technical output from local talent.41 There has been no dedicated AI ethics conference organized in Maldives yet.
However, a Maldives AI Forum was convened in October 2024,42 hosted by the private company Oxiqa,43 where UNESCO presented the work done for the Maldives AI RAM.
However, dedicated departments for AI ethics are being set up, subject to funds and national budget provisions.
Presently, no binding policy framework governs the adoption of digital tools in schools, although teachers are granted discretion to use such tools based on their individual preferences.
However, a recent UNESCO study (UNESCO, 2024) presents a more nuanced picture.
According to this report on information and communication technology in education in Maldives, 53 per cent of schools reported insufficient internet speed, particularly during peak hours.
This issue is compounded by a marked digital divide between the Greater Male' region and the outer islands, with 70 per cent of schools in the outer islands lacking adequate technical support.
Nearly half the schools (48 per cent) lack computer labs, limiting students’ ability to engage directly with digital technologies.
Maldives lacks higher education programmes that cover both the technical and ethical aspects of AI comprehensively.

economic.title: Economic
findings: Governing AI in Maldives The effective governance of AI in Maldives requires a strong and adaptive legal and policy foundation that upholds ethical standards while responding to the specific national context.
There are no AI-specific laws or guidelines in force.
Key enabling legislation like a Data Protection Bill, a Digital Services Bill and a Digital Identification Bill are under development.

Consultations underscored the importance of aligning AI regulations with international ethical standards, including transparency, fairness, human oversight and accountability, without creating overly burdensome restrictions that could impede innovation.
There is an opportunity to create a holistic regulatory framework that addresses ethical considerations for, and accountability of, AI technologies.
Maldives can adopt and adapt international best practices and standards in AI regulation, enhancing its global competitiveness and credibility.
Establishing regulations focused on ethical AI use can foster public trust in the AI sector.

Currently, the National Centre for Information Technology, under the Ministry of Homeland Security and Technology, is spearheading the AI masterplan initiative, with the Ministry of Economic Development contributing to certain components.
strengths: Stakeholders emphasized that regulatory approaches should maintain a balance between enabling innovation and ensuring robust ethical safeguards.
The rapid evolution of AI technologies makes it difficult for regulations to keep up, leading to potentially outdated or ineffective policies.
There are no data protection laws that adequately address the unique challenges posed by AI, leading to potential privacy violations and public mistrust.
Opportunities • Development of a comprehensive AI masterplan for Maldives.
Opportunities • Development of comprehensive AI training programmes.
There is an opportunity to create structured training programmes that cater to various skill levels, from basic digital literacy to advanced AI competencies.

Encouraging collaboration Fostering collaborations between government institutions, civil society, academia and the private sector can create a more robust and supportive ecosystem for AI innovation.
This collaborative approach will help create a comprehensive and inclusive plan that addresses the unique needs and challenges of Maldives.

This also requires that Maldives’ Digital Services Bill and Data Protection Bill cover accessibility needs by ensuring that digital services and products based on AI systems are perceivable, operable, understandable, and robust for persons with disabilities.

This could lead to increased availability of Maldives-specific AI training data (in Dhivehi and including culturally specific datasets) through standardized open-source repositories, for example, while protecting data privacy with a comprehensive data protection law.
gaps: Currently, Maldives lacks a national AI strategy, though an AI masterplan for 2025–2035 is being developed.
Stakeholders highlighted the urgent need to finalize these frameworks to establish clarity around data governance, privacy, and accountability for AI systems.

Notably, Maldives’ ranking of 177 out of 194 countries on the International Telecommunication Union's Global Cybersecurity Index underscores the need to strengthen its cybersecurity frameworks, particularly to manage AI-related risks.
Challenges • Limited expertise in AI regulation.
